p: SARS-CoV, which originated in China and then spread to other parts of the world with hospital-acquired infectious cases, had a mortality rate of 10% and was transmitted to 8000 people during an 8-month outbreak in 2002â€“2003 (Ksiazek et al. 2003; Yin and Wunderink 2018; Luk et al. 2019). In 2012, when MERS-CoV emerged in the Arabian Peninsula, it spread to 27 countries with a 35.6% mortality rate in 2220 cases (Yin and Wunderink 2018; Zaki et al. 2012; Farooq et al. 2020). It is already known that both SARS and MERS are zoonotic viruses showing hospital-acquired and human-to-human transmission (Yin and Wunderink 2018). Similar dynamics apply to this new strain named COVID-19 (CoVs), detected in Wuhan, Hubei Province, China, in December 2019, and the current rate of mortality is about 2% (Chen et al. 2020; Huang et al. 2020). It is also known that CoVs can use different receptors and pathways when entering the cell (Tortorici et al. 2019).
